title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act is titled the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". It includes findings related to the Act. The "Flood Control Act of 1944" aimed to promote economic development in the US. The Oahe Dam Project, a part of this program, benefits the national economy but flooded Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation land. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project flooded the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, causing economic and cultural damage to the tribe. Congress compensated the tribe for the losses incurred. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act (Public Law 106-511; 114 Stat. 2365) created the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund to provide compensation to members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund aims to compensate tribe members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project and to capitalize the fund. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe aims to provide equitable compensation for tribe members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe seeks fair compensation for tribal members who lost land in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, emphasizing the need for adequate compensation from the United States. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe and member landowners should be adequately compensated for the land lost in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. Amendments are made to ensure fair compensation for tribal members. Amendments define "member landowner" as a Tribe member owning land on the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation acquired for the Oahe Dam project. "Power program" refers to the program under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to receive 25 percent of the power program funds deposited into the Treasury annually. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to receive 25 percent of the power program funds deposited into the Treasury annually, starting from October 1, 2004, until the total amount deposited equals $290,722,958. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund is amended to receive 25 percent of the power program funds annually until it reaches $290,722,958, including interest accrued as of October 1, 2001. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund will receive 25 percent of power program funds annually until it reaches $290,722,958, including interest determined by the Lehman Government Bond Index. Amendments include changes in fiscal year start date and redesignation of paragraphs. The plan allows for additional compensation to member landowners for land acquisition in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. It also assists the Tribe in processing claims of heirs of member landowners. The Secretary of the Interior will provide records to the Tribe to help process claims of heirs of member landowners for land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to include member landowners in eligibility for certain programs and services.
